title: Uber is vowing to fight the new California bill that threatens to turn its drivers into employees
text:
Carlo Allegri/Reuters

Uber plans to fight to keep its drivers as independent contractors after California lawmakers passed a bill that would force "gig economy" companies to treat their workers as employees.

Assembly Bill 5 "does not automatically reclassify any ride-share drivers from independent contractors to employees," Uber's chief legal officer told reporters on Wednesday, according to The Wall Street Journal.

Uber drivers are "properly classified as independent," Tony West said, adding that the ride-hailing giant would "respond to claims of misclassification in arbitration and in court."

Uber plans to fight to keep its drivers as independent contractors after California lawmakers passed a bill forcing "gig economy" companies to treat their workers as employees.

State senators this week passed Assembly Bill 5, which threatens to reclassify hundreds of thousands of Uber and Lyft drivers in California as employees — entitling them to benefits such as a minimum hourly wage and unemployment insurance and potentially setting a precedent for other states. The bill is expected to be signed into law and take effect January 1.

But Uber's chief legal officer, Tony West, told reporters on Wednesday that the bill "does not automatically reclassify any (ride-hailing) drivers from independent contractors to employees," according to The Wall Street Journal.

West argued that the bill raised the bar for workers to be considered contractors but that the ride-hailing giant cleared it, The Journal reported. Uber drivers are "properly classified as independent," West reportedly said, adding that the firm would "respond to claims of misclassification in arbitration and in court."

"AB5 does not provide drivers with benefits, nor does it give drivers the right to organize," he added, according to The Journal. "In fact, the bill currently says nothing about ride-share drivers."

Uber and Lyft have previously downplayed the bill as a qualification of existing law, argued it would hurt workers by reducing flexibility, and claimed it would lead to customers paying more. Lyft has also said the bill would lower some of its costs and give it more control over drivers.
